title: Part B
stimulusHtml:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.

  • Decimal approximations must be correct to three places after the decimal point by rounding or truncating. Decimal values of 0 MathType@MTEF@5@5@+=feaagCart1ev2aqatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbuLwBLnhiov2DGi1BTfMBaeXatLxBI9gBaerbd9wDYLwzYbItLDharqqtubsr4rNCHbGeaGqiFC0pg9uqGrpepeea0dXdHaVhbbe9u8qqaqFr0xc9pk0xj9qqaqFj0dh9qq=xfr=JarFfpeea0=as0=fs0di9uqFr0=vr0=vr0db8meaabaqaciGacaGaaeqabaWaaeaaeaaakeaacaaIWaaaaa@39B6@ in final digits need not be reported ( 2.000=2.00=2.0=2 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@4570@ ).

  • A decimal presentation error occurs when a response is complete and correct, but the answer is reported to fewer digits than required.

  • The first decimal presentation error in this question does not earn the point. For each additional part of this question that requires a decimal approximation and contains a decimal presentation error, the response is eligible to earn the point.

  • If the response includes an additional, complete limit statement (e.g., lim x→−∞ g(x)=∞ MathType@MTEF@5@5@@470F@ ), the value of the limit must be correct.
descriptions:
The student response includes none of these criteria.

  • Value of x=1.057 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3EA6@ with no incorrect values. No supporting work is required.

  • End behavior with limit notation. A correct limit statement must have four components: “lim”, “ x→∞ MathType@MTEF@5@5@+=feaagCart1ev2aqatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbuLwBLnhiov2DGi1BTfMBaeXatLxBI9gBaerbd9wDYLwzYbItLDharqqtubsr4rNCHbGeaGqiFC0pg9uqGrpepeea0dXdHaVhbbe9u8qqaqFr0xc9pk0xj9qqaqFj0dh9qq=xfr=JarFfpeea0=as0=fs0di9uqFr0=vr0=vr0db8meaabaqaciGacaGaaeqabaWaaeaaeaaakeaacaWG4bGaeyOKH4QaeyOhIukaaa@3D57@ ”, the function g MathType@MTEF@5@5@+=feaagCart1ev2aqatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbuLwBLnhiov2DGi1BTfMBaeXatLxBI9gBaerbd9wDYLwzYbItLDharqqtubsr4rNCHbGeaGqiFC0pg9uqGrpepeea0dXdHaVhbbe9u8qqaqFr0xc9pk0xj9qqaqFj0dh9qq=xfr=JarFfpeea0=as0=fs0di9uqFr0=vr0=vr0db8meaabaqaciGacaGaaeqabaWaaeaaeaaakeaacaWGNbaaaa@39E8@ , and 0 MathType@MTEF@5@5@+=feaagCart1ev2aqatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbuLwBLnhiov2DGi1BTfMBaeXatLxBI9gBaerbd9wDYLwzYbItLDharqqtubsr4rNCHbGeaGqiFC0pg9uqGrpepeea0dXdHaVhbbe9u8qqaqFr0xc9pk0xj9qqaqFj0dh9qq=xfr=JarFfpeea0=as0=fs0di9uqFr0=vr0=vr0db8meaabaqaciGacaGaaeqabaWaaeaaeaaakeaacaaIWaaaaa@39B6@ . Examples that earn the point include lim x→∞ g (x)=0 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@46FC@ , lim x→∞ g=0 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@4315@ , lim x→∞ g (x)→0 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@47E3@ , lim x→∞ g→0 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@43FC@ , lim x→∞ g(x)    0 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@4A99@ , lim x→∞ g    0 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@4843@ .

  • Two components. One of the following:

    • Correct value for which g (x)=2 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3F91@ that is not expressed as decimal approximations

    • Correct value for which g (x)=2 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3F91@ with a decimal presentation error

      AND One of the following:

    • Correct end behavior statement without use of limit notation

    • Correct end behavior statement with incorrect limit notation

    • Correct limit statement that is missing “ x→∞ MathType@MTEF@5@5@+=feaagCart1ev2aqatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbuLwBLnhiov2DGi1BTfMBaeXatLxBI9gBaerbd9wDYLwzYbItLDharqqtubsr4rNCHbGeaGqiFC0pg9uqGrpepeea0dXdHaVhbbe9u8qqaqFr0xc9pk0xj9qqaqFj0dh9qq=xfr=JarFfpeea0=as0=fs0di9uqFr0=vr0=vr0db8meaabaqaciGacaGaaeqabaWaaeaaeaaakeaacaWG4bGaeyOKH4QaeyOhIukaaa@3D57@ ”
